abstract: Fas is a type-I membrane protein that transduces an apoptotic signal. Binding of Fas ligand or agonistic anti-Fas antibody to Fas kills the cells by apoptosis. Studies in the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans have suggested that proteases such as interleukin-1 beta-converting enzyme (ICE) or the product of the C. elegans cell-death gene ced-3 are involved in apoptotic signal transduction. The activity of ICE can be inhibited by the product of crmA, a cytokine-response modifier gene encoded by cowpox virus. We report here that expression of crmA inhibits cytotoxicity induced by anti-Fas antibody or tumour necrosis factor (TNF). We have found a specific ICE inhibitor tetrapeptide (acetyl-Tyr-Val-Ala-Asp-chloromethylketone) that also prevents apoptosis induced by anti-Fas antibody. These results suggest an involvement of an ICE-like protease in Fas-mediated apoptosis and TNF-induced cytotoxicity.

We have used a combination of genetics and pharmacology to assess the effects of reduced DNA methyltransferase activity on ApcMin-induced intestinal neoplasia in mice. A reduction in the DNA methyltransferase activity in Min mice due to heterozygosity of the DNA methyltransferase gene, in conjunction with a weekly dose of the DNA methyltransferase inhibitor 5-aza-deoxycytidine, reduced the average number of intestinal adenomas from 113 in the control mice to only 2 polyps in the treated heterozygotes. Hence, DNA methyltransferase activity contributes substantially to tumor development in this mouse model of intestinal neoplasia. Our results argue against an oncogenic effect of DNA hypomethylation. Moreover, they are consistent with a role for DNA methyltransferase in the generation of the C to T transitions seen at high frequency in human colorectal tumors.

THE Fas/APO-1 receptor is one of the major regulators of apoptosis1á€-7. We report here that Fas/APO-1-mediated apoptosis requires the activation of a new class of cysteine proteases, including interleukin-lβ-converting enzyme (ICE)8á€-10, which are homologous to the product of the Caenorhabditis elegans cell-death gene ced-3 (refs 11, 12). Triggering of Fas/APO-1 rapidly stimulated the proteolytic activity of ICE. Overexpression of ICE, achieved by electroporation and microinjection, strongly potentiated Fas/ APO-1-mediated cell death. In addition, inhibition of ICE activity by protease inhibitors, as well as by transient expression of the pox virus-derived serpin inhibitor CrmA or an antisense ICE construct, substantially suppressed Fas/APO-1-triggered cell death. We conclude that activation of ICE or an ICE-related protease is a critical event in Fas/APO-1-mediated cell death.

After germinal center B cells undergo somatic mutation and antigen selection, they become either memory B cells or plasma cells, but the signal requirements that control entry into either pathway have been unclear. When purified human germinal center cells were cultured with interleukin-2, interleukin-10, and cells expressing CD40 ligand, cells with characteristics of memory B cells were generated. Removal of CD40 ligand from the system resulted in terminal differentiation of germinal center B cells into cells with the characteristics of plasma cells. These results indicate that CD40 ligand directs the differentiation of germinal center B cells toward memory B cells rather than toward plasma cells.

B61, a cytokine-inducible endothelial gene product, is the ligand for the Eck receptor protein tyrosine kinase (RPTK). Expression of a B61-immunoglobulin chimera showed that B61 could act as an angiogenic factor in vivo and a chemoattractant for endothelial cells in vitro. The Eck RPTK was activated by tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha) through induction of B61, and an antibody to B61 attenuated angiogenesis induced by TNF-alpha but not by basic fibroblast growth factor. This finding suggests the existence of an autocrine or paracrine loop involving activation of the Eck RPTK by its inducible ligand B61 after an inflammatory stimulus, the net effect of which would be to promote angiogenesis, a hallmark of chronic inflammation.

Endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide; LPS) activates a wide variety of host defense mechanisms. In mammals LPS binding protein (LBP) and CD14 interact with LPS to mediate cellular activation. Using sucrose density gradients and a fluorescent endotoxin derivative we have investigated the mechanism of LPS binding to LBP and the soluble form of CD14 (sCD14). LPS binds to LBP to form two types of complex; at low ratios of LPS to LBP complexes with one molecule of LBP and 1-2 molecules of LPS predominate, while at high ratios of LPS to LBP a large aggregate of LBP and LPS predominates. Complexes of LPS with sCD14 do not form large aggregates, consisting of only 1-2 LPS bound to a single sCD14 even at high multiples of LPS to sCD14. LBP catalyzes LPS binding to sCD14. Catalysis by LBP apparently occurs because LBP provides a pathway for LPS to bind to sCD14 which avoids the necessity for LPS monomers in aqueous solution. The dissociation constants for LPS·LBP and LPS·sCD14 complexes were determined to be 3.5 × 10−9 and 29 × 10−9M, respectively. These numbers suggest that when LBP and sCD14 are present at roughly equal concentrations as they are in normal human plasma and compete for limited LPS, the LPS will predominantly associate with LBP. Using sucrose density gradients and a fluorescent endotoxin derivative we have investigated the mechanism of LPS binding to LBP and the soluble form of CD14 (sCD14). The exposure of organisms as diverse as horseshoe crabs and mammals to endotoxin (lipopolysaccharide, LPS)1( 1The abbreviations used are: LPSlipopolysaccharideLBPLPS binding proteinsCD14soluble CD14FITCfluorescein isothiocyanateASD2-(p-azido-salicylamido)ethyl-1,3’-dithiopropionyl. ) results in the activation of a wide variety of host defense mechanisms. Recent studies of mammalian cells have described a unified pathway for the LPS-dependent activation of many cell types including monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils, endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and some epithelial cell lines. The common elements of the pathway include LPS binding protein (LBP), a 60-kDa plasma glycoprotein, and CD14, a 55-kDa glycoprotein. On monocytes, macrophages, and neutrophils, CD14 is present as a glycerophosphoinositol tailed membrane (mCD14) component (1Haziot A. Chen S. Ferrero E. Low M.G. Silber R. Goyert S.M. J. Immunol. 1988; 141: 547-552PubMed Google Scholar). In the presence of LBP, LPS binds to the mCD14 and initiates cellular activation (2Schumann R.R. Leong S.R. Flaggs G.W. Gray P.W. Wright S.D. Mathison J.C. Tobias P.S. Ulevitch R.J. Science. 1990; 249: 1429-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (1378) Google Scholar, 3Wright S.D. Ramos R.A. Tobias P.S. Ulevitch R.J. Mathison J.C. Science. 1990; 249: 1431-1433Crossref PubMed Scopus (3398) Google Scholar). However, other LPS-responsive cells such as endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and some epithelial cell lines do not express mCD14. Instead, they have a receptor for complexes of LPS with the soluble form of CD14 (sCD14), which circulates in plasma without a glycerophosphoinositol tail (4Pugin J. Schurer-Maly C.-C. Leturcq D. Here again, LBP facilitates the formation of LPS·sCD14 complexes. lipopolysaccharide LPS binding protein soluble CD14 fluorescein isothiocyanate 2-(p-azido-salicylamido)ethyl-1,3’-dithiopropionyl. In this report we describe the use of fluorescein-derivatized LPS (FITC-LPS) to permit continuous monitoring of the formation of LPS·LBP and LPS·sCD14 complexes. Heretofore it has not been possible to observe the formation of LPS·LBP and LPS·sCD14 complexes on a real time basis with a method that also permits the quantitative determination of kinetic and equilibrium parameters for formation of these complexes. We also describe our characterization of LPS·LBP and LPS·sCD14 complexes using sucrose density gradients. Others have used nondenaturing polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis to characterize LPS protein complexes (7Hailman E. Lichenstein H.S. Wurfel M.M. Miller D.S. Johnson D.A. Kelley M. Busse L.A. Zukowski M.M. Wright S.D. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (617) Google Scholar), but we found sucrose density gradients more useful since they permit more analysis of the separated components. Taken together, we conclude from these results that LBP catalyses the formation of LPS·sCD14 complexes and suggest a mechanistic pathway by which this occurs. Human recombinant soluble sCD14 was isolated by immunoaffinity chromatography (Immunopure Protein G IgG Orientation Kit, Pierce, Rockford, IL) using monoclonal antibody 63D3 (American Type Culture Collection, Rockville, MD) from the supernatants of Chinese hamster ovary cells transfected, essentially as described in Ref. 12Lee J.-D. A. 1993; 90: 9930-9934Crossref PubMed Scopus (171) Google Scholar, with the cDNA for human CD14. To prepare 35S-labeled sCD14 and 35S-labeled sLBP CD14 or LBP, expressing Chinese hamster ovary cells were metabolically labeled with [35S]Met (DuPont NEN, Boston, MA). The labeled proteins were prepared from 24-h culture supernatants by immunopurification using mAb 63D3 for sCD14 and mAb 18G4 for LBP. The mAb 18G4 as well as mAb 2B5, with specificity for human LBP, were kindly provided by D. Leturcq and A. Moriarty (R. W. Johnson Pharmaceutical Research Institute, La Jolla, CA). [125I]ASD-LPS was prepared from S. minnesota Re595 LPS as described (11Tobias P.S. Soldau K. Ulevitch R.J. J. Exp. Med. 1986; 164: 777-793Crossref PubMed Scopus (423) Google Scholar). 3H-Labeled LPS and non-radioactive LPS from Salmonella typhimurium PR122(Rc) was obtained either from R. Munford (13Munford R.S. DeVeaux L.C. Cronan Jr., J.E. Rick P.D. J. Immunol. Methods. 1992; 148: 115-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar) or commercially (List Biologicals, Campbell, CA). Sucrose density gradients were centrifuged for 1 h 20 min at 4°C in a pre-chilled TV-865 rotor (DuPont, Burbank, CA) at 55,000 rpm. The gradients were 4 ml of 5-20% sucrose in 0.05 M phosphate, 0.14 M NaCl, 2 mM EDTA, pH 7.4, layered onto 0.2 ml of 40% sucrose. The samples were incubated at 37°C for 15 min and then chilled to 4°C before 0.2 ml was layered on top of the gradient; aliquots of the samples were removed before centrifugation to determine total radioactive material for calculation of recovery. Typically, recovery of radioactive material from the gradients was 65-95%. Fluorescence was monitored using an SLM 8000 fluorimeter (SLM Instruments, Urbana, IL) with excitation at 490 nm and emission at 520 nm. In plain glass cuvettes (7 mm × 45 mm, Sienco, Morrison, CO) 35S-labeled LBP was observed to disappear from solution at a significant rate, presumably by adsorption to the glass (data not shown). In order to minimize binding of LBP and FITC-LPS to the cuvettes, they were filled with 10 mg/ml bovine serum albumin (Sigma) in water for 1 h after which they were extensively rinsed with water and stored moist at 4°C. As indicated by the slow declines of fluorescence seen at long times in some figures, this procedure is not totally successful. Reactions were conducted in 50 mM phosphate, 100 mM NaCl, 2 mM EDTA at pH 7.4, except for the experiments reported in Fig. 3 b which were conducted in 10 mM phosphate, 2 mM EDTA, at pH 7.4 with KCl as required. Apparent pseudo-first order rate constants and dissociation constants were obtained from the fluorescence data using the curve fitting procedures of SigmaPlot (Jandel Scientific, San Rafael, CA). When loss of fluorescence due to adsorption to the cuvette was significant (see above), it was included as a time linear component of the overall fluorescent change. In some instances the amount of FITC-LPS approached 10% of the binding protein. Therefore, in all cases, Kdvalues were obtained by fitting the data to a “quadratic” hyperbola rather than a “rectangular” hyperbola as defined by Equation 1, F=(∆F/[L])*(((L+P+K)-SQRT((L+P+K)2-4*L*P))/2)(Eq. 1) On-line formulae not verified for accuracy where F is the observed fluorescence, L and P are the concentrations of FITC-LPS and protein, respectively, SQRT is the square root operator, and Δ F and K, the overall fluorescence change and the dissociation constant respectively, are the fitted parameters. The photoaffinity probe [125I] ASD-LPS (8 × 10−9M) was incubated with several mixtures of sCD14 and LBP (see legend to Fig. 6) at 37°C for 15 min before chilling to 4°C for photolysis as described previously (11Tobias P.S. Soldau K. Ulevitch R.J. J. Exp. Med. 1986; 164: 777-793Crossref PubMed Scopus (423) Google Scholar). The proteins were then separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis using a 10% acrylamide gel and detected by autoradiography after Coomassie staining to detect protein molecular weight markers (Sigma). When 3H-labeled LPS or 35S-labeled LBP are separately subjected to sucrose density gradient sedimentation, their mobilities are quite different as shown in Fig. 1, panels a and b, respectively. The concentrations of 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled LBP used, as well as the mole ratios of the incubation mixtures and the resulting sucrose density gradient peaks, are given in Table I. As indicated by the mobilities of albumin and ovalbumin (data not shown), 35S-labeled LBP sediments with the mobility expected for a 60-kDa protein. However, 3H-labeled LPS has a mobility considerably higher than would be warranted by its molecular weight of 4000 (13Munford R.S. DeVeaux L.C. Cronan Jr., J.E. Rick P.D. J. Immunol. Methods. 1992; 148: 115-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), indicating a high degree of aggregation. When 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled LBP are mixed and incubated for 15 min at 37°C before sedimentation, the mobility of the 3H-labeled LPS shifts to the mobility of LBP while the mobility of the 35S-labeled LBP does not increase (Fig. 1, panel c). This could be the result either of LPS binding to LBP or simply disaggregation of the 3H-labeled LPS. Since [125I]ASD-LPS and LBP can be demonstrated to form a complex at lower concentrations than used here (see Fig. 6), we conclude that a complex of 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled LBP has formed and that this complex has the mobility of 35S-labeled LBP. As the amount of 3H-labeled LPS used is increased, a high mobility complex 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled LBP is formed (panels c-e). However, the mobility of the complex is not determined by the absolute amount of 3H-labeled LPS used, but rather the 3H-LPS:35S-LBP ratio, as is seen by comparing panel f with d and e. In summary, these data suggest that 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled LBP may form two sorts of complex depending on the LPS:LBP ratio. One complex contains a single LBP and a small number (1Haziot A. Chen S. Ferrero E. Low M.G. Silber R. Goyert S.M. J. Immunol. 1988; 141: 547-552PubMed Google Scholar, 2Schumann R.R. Leong S.R. Flaggs G.W. Gray P.W. Wright S.D. Mathison J.C. Tobias P.S. Ulevitch R.J. Science. 1990; 249: 1429-1431Crossref PubMed Scopus (1378) Google Scholar) of LPS molecules. The other contains a large number of LPS and probably multiple LBP.Table IFig. 1 sucrose density gradients: LPS and LBP Open table in a new tab When 3H-labeled LPS, 35S-labeled sCD14, and LBP are mixed in various concentrations (see Table II) and subjected to sucrose density gradient sedimentation, an 3H-LPS·35S-sCD14 complex forms only in the presence of LBP, as shown in Fig. 2. As was the case with 35S-labeled LBP, 3H-labeled LPS and 35S-labeled sCD14 sediment distinctly differently in the sucrose gradients (Fig. 2, panels a and b). However, in contrast to the case with 35S-labeled LBP, no obvious 3H-LPS·35S-sCD14 complex is formed when the two are simply mixed (Fig. 2, panel c). Addition of a small amount of LBP does enable an 3H-LPS·35S-sCD14 complex to form (Fig. 2, panel d). With 35S-labeled sCD14, however, only one size of 3H-LPS·35S-sCD14 complex is seen despite the use of relatively very high concentrations of 3H-labeled LPS (Fig. 2, panels e and f) compared to the concentrations used to generate large complexes of 3H-labeled LPS with 35S-labeled LBP. The mole ratio of LPS:sCD14 in the complexes (see Table II) is distinctly less than that in the incubation mixtures when LPS is in excess. Both the size and composition of the LPS·sCD14 complexes suggest that sCD14 can only complex with a limited number of LPS molecules.Table IIFig. 2 sucrose density gradients: LPS, sCD14, and LBP Open table in a new tab To develop a system that would permit real time determinations of the kinetics and equilibria governing interaction of LPS with LBP and sCD14 we asked whether the fluorescence signal of FITC-LPS would change upon complexation with LBP or sCD14. We observed an approximately 3-fold enhancement of fluorescence. The physical basis for this enhancement is not totally defined, but probably derives from relief of self-quenching in aggregates of FITC-LPS. S. minnesota Re595 LPS is undoubtedly strongly aggregated as are many types of LPS (14Takayama K. Mitchell D.H. Din Z.Z. Mukerjee P. Li C. Coleman D.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 2241-2244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We observed that n-octyl-β-D-glucopyranoside also enhances the fluorescence, again suggesting that aggregate dissociation is responsible. As indicated by the sucrose density gradients of Figs. 1 and 2, incubation of 3H-labeled LPS with excess LBP or sCD14 reduces it's sedimentation velocity essentially to that of the protein, suggesting disaggregation of the 3H-labeled LPS. The time dependence of the fluorescence change when 4.2 × 10−9M FITC-LPS reacts with a 10-fold excess of LBP (4.2 × 10-8M) is shown in Fig. 3 a. The initial fluorescence is that of the buffer alone. FITC-LPS and LBP were added at points “a” and “b” respectively. The fluorescence change from 120 s, a time just beyond point b, to 250 s was fit as a first order process. The individual data points and the calculated first order curve are shown in the inset with kexp = 4.7 × 10-2 s-1. Experiments like these were conducted at a variety of FITC-LPS and LBP concentrations to characterize the kinetics of FITC·LPS·LBP complex formation. Over 2 orders of magnitude in [LBP], 4 × 10-10 to 4 × 10-8M, kexp did not change significantly. These data suggest that formation of FITC·LPS·LBP complexes from LPSagg and LBP is a two-step process as shown in Fig. S1 and that the molecularity of LBP does not change during the rate-limiting step. Because we can directly observe LBP bound to LPS aggregates (see Fig. 1) we favor a reaction scheme for FITC-LPS-LBP formation in which LBP rapidly binds to FITC-LPS aggregates. Subsequently, FITC·LPS·LBP complexes dissociate from these aggregates in the rate-limiting step. The rate of FITC-LPS-LBP formation was found to be strongly dependent on the salt concentration. The value of kexp was determined in 10 mM phosphate buffer at several concentrations of KCl as shown in Fig. 3 b. This observation is consistent with the idea that FITC-LPS-LBP formation involves transfer of hydrophobic structures such as the fatty acid tails of lipid A through a polar environment (15Tanford C. The Hydrophobic Effect: Formation of Micelles and Biological Membranes. Wiley-Interscience, New York1980Google Scholar). The KDfor FITC·LPS·LBP complexes was obtained by analyzing the dependence on [LBP] of the difference in fluorescence between FITC-LPS alone and at the end of the association reaction. The data and their fit to an hyperbola are shown in Fig. 3 c from which Kd= 0.81(± 0.34) × 10−9M. The average of three determinations of KDwas 3.5 × 10−9M with a range of 0.81 to 6.1 × 10−9M. As one would expect, unfluoresceinated Re595 LPS competes with FITC-LPS for binding to LBP (data not shown). Furthermore, monoclonal antibody 2B5, which binds LBP and blocks LPS binding to recombinant mCD14 expressing Chinese hamster ovary cells (16Gegner J.A. Ulevitch R.J. Tobias P.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5320-5325Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar) also blocks FITC-LPS binding to LBP (data not shown). Because complexes of LPS with either mCD14 or sCD14 are critical for activation of most LPS-sensitive cells, we investigated the reaction of FITC-LPS with sCD14. The data of Fig. 4 demonstrate the role of LBP in the binding of FITC-LPS to sCD14. At time A, 10 ng/ml FITC-LPS (4.5 × 10−9M) was added to the cuvette, followed by 10 μg/ml sCD14 (1.8 × 10-7M) at time B. The fluorescence does not change until time C, when LBP is added at 0.04 μg/ml (6.6 × 10-10M). At the end of the ensuing fluorescence change, i.e. at about 300 s elapsed time, one may ask whether LBP has limited the reaction, since it is at the lowest concentration. Addition of another aliquot of LBP at C’ does not cause a further fluorescence change, nor does addition of another aliquot of sCD14 at B’. Only addition of more FITC-LPS at A’ causes a further increase in fluorescence. Since LBP was not limiting at the end of the first reaction, since almost no reaction occurred in its absence, and because 7 mol of FITC-LPS/mol of LBP bound to sCD14, we conclude that LBP must have catalyzed the binding of FITC-LPS to sCD14. From four similar experiments, the KDdetermination averaged 2.9 × 10-8M (± 30%). Changing the FITC-LPS concentration 4-fold, and changing the LBP concentration 2-fold had no observable effect on the value of the KD. This is consistent with the sucrose density gradient data which suggest that LBP is not a constituent of the FITC·LPS·sCD14 complexes. The kinetics of formation of FITC·LPS·sCD14 complexes as a function of LBP and sCD14 concentrations are shown in Fig. 5, b and c. In the absence of LBP a rate constant of 1.7 × 10-4 s-1 was observed. Fig. 5, b and c, suggest that as the protein concentration increases, there is a change in the rate-limiting step of the overall reaction, as discussed in the context of Fig. S1. As discussed above for Fig. 4, when LBP is at a low concentration relative to sCD14, the FITC-LPS transfers to sCD14. However, the determined values for the relative KDvalues of FITC-LPS-LBP and FITC-LPS-sCD14, 3.5 × 10−9M and 29 × 10−9M, respectively, suggest that as the ratio of LBP to sCD14 changes, the association of FITC-LPS with LBP and sCD14 should change. More specifically, at an LBP:sCD14 ratio of 1:8 the FITC-LPS should be approximately equally distributed between the two proteins. Since the fluorescence signals of the FITC·LPS·LBP and FITC·LPS·sCD14 complexes are essentially identical and will not permit verification of this prediction, we have used the radioiodinated, photoactivatable derivative of Re595 LPS, namely [125I]ASD-LPS, to verify this prediction. Fig. 6 shows the relative labeling of LBP and sCD14 when 5 × 10−9M (0.3 μg/ml) LBP and varying amounts of sCD14 are incubated and photolyzed with 8 × 10−9M [125I]ASD-LPS. As can be seen the labeling of the two proteins is roughly equal at an sCD14 concentration of between 2 × 10-8 and 5 × 10-8M, verifiying the prediction made from the values of KDdetermined with FITC-LPS. Heretofore it has not been possible to monitor the interaction of LPS with any LPS binding protein on a continuous, quantitative basis to explore the mechanism, kinetics, and equilibria of the reaction. While several strategems have been employed to determine binding affinities for LPS with several binding proteins (17Tobias P.S. Soldau K. Ulevitch R.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 10867-10871Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Wainwright N.R. Miller R.J. Paus E. Novitsky T.J. Fletcher M.A. McKenna T.M. Williams T. Nowotny A. Spitzer J.J. Ziegler E.J. Cellular and Molecular Aspects of Endotoxin Reactions. Elsevier Sciences Publishers, Amsterdam1990: 315-325Google Scholar, 19Gazzano-Santoro H. Parent J.B. Grinna L. Horwitz A. Parsons T. Theofan G. Elsbach P. Weiss J. Conlon P.J. Infect. Immun. 1992; 60: 4754-4761Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 20Gazzano-Santoro H. Meszaros K. Birr C. Carroll S.F. Theofan G. Horwitz A.H. Lim E. Aberle S. Kasler H. Parent J.B. Infect. Immun. 1994; 62: 1185-1191Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), the kinetics of the binding reactions have not been measurable. Through the use of FITC-LPS, many, although not all, of the difficulties are removed. If, as we hypothesize, the increase in fluorescence derives from relief of fluorescein self-quenching in an FITC-LPS aggregate, then the method will not be useful for types of FITC-LPS which do not aggregate. However, these may be relatively few given the strongly amphipathic nature of the lipid A moiety of LPS. Additionally, not all types of LPS, and not all LPS partial structures, have readily derivatizable groups in appropriate parts of the molecule. Indeed, we were unable to observe any fluorescence change when the FITC derivative of Escherichia coli 0111:B4 LPS bound to LBP (data not shown). Wistrom-Aurell et al.2( 2Wistrom-Aurell et al., manuscript submitted for publication. ) have observed that the fluorescein in the FITC derivative of E. coli 0111:B4 LPS is probably more distantly removed from the lipid a moiety than is the fluorescein in the FITC-LPS used here; thus self-quenching in that derivative is probably less pronounced. Nevertheless, the opportunity to make any real time, continuous measurement of even one LPS binding to LBP and sCD14 has considerable value. The reactions between FITC-LPS and other LPS binding proteins such as bactericidal/permeability increasing protein, cholesterol ester transport protein, and Limulus anti-lipopolysaccharide factor are currently under study and will be described elsewhere. We conclude that LBP catalyzes the reaction of LPS with sCD14 for the following reasons. If LBP were a stoichiometric partner in the final complexes formed, this should be visible in the sucrose density gradients of Fig. 2, but it is not. LBP should be labeled by [125I]ASD-LPS in the presence of any concentration of sCD14, but, as shown in Fig. 6, it is not. And if LBP is a component of the FITC·LPS·sCD14 complexes, the concentration of LBP should alter the apparent binding constant obtained when sCD14 is increased, but it does not. Thus three lines of evidence argue that LBP is not a constituent of the final complexes. Furthermore, Figs. 3 and 5 b show that LBP accelerates the reaction and that it delivers anywhere from 7 to nearly 500 molecules of FITC-LPS to sCD14. Thus LBP accelerates the reaction, LBP is not consumed in the reaction, and it does not perturb the final equilibrium. Thus we conclude that it is fair to claim that LBP acts as a catalyst in the reactions described. Two possible reaction pathways which are potentially consistent with the kinetic data for the reaction of aggregated FITC-LPS (FITC-LPSagg) with LBP are summarized in in reactions 1-4 of Fig. S1. If the pathway involving reactions 1 and 2 is operative, then LBP reacts with FITC-LPSagg followed by dissociation of complexes of LBP with monomeric FITC-LPS. In this sequence, reaction 2 would be the rate-limiting step since reaction 2 involves no change in the molecularity of the reaction and the rate of LPS·LBP complex formation was observed to be independent of the LBP concentration. If the alternative pathway involving reactions 3 and 4 is operative, monomers of FITC-LPS dissociate from the FITC-LPSagg and then react with LBP. In this sequence reaction 3 would be the rate-limiting step. Between these two pathways for LPS-LBP formation, we favor the upper pathway 1 and 2 primarily for the following reasons. The first is that complexes of LBP with LPS aggregates are directly observable in the sucrose density gradients. Complex formation via 3 and 4 does not involve any buildup of LBP bound to LPS aggregates since reaction 3 is rate-limiting. Second, if LBP reacted only with LPS monomers, because it has a higher affinity for LPS than does sCD14, LBP should inhibit the reaction of FITC-LPS with sCD14, not catalyze it. Undoubtedly there is some low equilibrium concentration of LPS monomers (21Din Z.Z. Mukerjee P. Kastowsky M. Takayama K. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 4579-4586Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) which could react directly either with LBP or sCD14. Presumably it is this pathway which provides for the spontaneous reaction of FITC-LPS with sCD14 with a rate constant of 1.7 × 10-4 s-1. Fig. 5, b and c, suggests that as the concentration of either protein changes, the overall reaction undergoes a change in rate-limiting step. This is typically observed when one step of a multistep reaction is subject to catalysis (22Jencks W.P. Catalysis in Chemistry and Enzymology. McGraw-Hill, New York1969Google Scholar). For example, given the foregoing discussion, in Fig. 5 c we propose that the rate-limiting step is “5” at low [sCD14] and “1” at high [sCD14]. Under this interpretation, the value observed for kexp,max from the data of both Fig. 5, b and c, should be approximately 4.2 × 10-2 s-1, i.e. the rate constant for dissociation of an FITC·LPS·LBP complex from FITC-LPSagg-LBP. The observed values are 8.9 × 10-2 s-1 and 6.6 × 10-2 s-1, respectively. Given the scatter in the data and the other vagaries in these reactions which we have experienced, we feel that theory and experiment are in acceptable agreement. Thus we conclude that the pathway for the formation of LPS·sCD14 complexes catalyzed by LBP is that which is shown in boldface in Fig. S1. Biologically, these results have several implications. As noted previously, recent work has suggested a catalytic role for LBP in assisting the presentation of LPS to sCD14 and that catalytic role is clearly supported by these results, as is the conclusion that sCD14 only binds a small number of LPS molecules (7Hailman E. Lichenstein H.S. Wurfel M.M. Miller D.S. Johnson D.A. Kelley M. Busse L.A. Zukowski M.M. Wright S.D. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (617) Google Scholar). While one might wish to extrapolate and suggest that LBP also catalyzes the binding of LPS to mCD14 (7Hailman E. Lichenstein H.S. Wurfel M.M. Miller D.S. Johnson D.A. Kelley M. Busse L.A. Zukowski M.M. Wright S.D. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (617) Google Scholar), i.e. CD14 on monocyte or neutrophil membranes, recent results from this laboratory show that LBP remains associated with mCD14 bearing cells when the cells are incubated with LPS·LBP complexes (16Gegner J.A. Ulevitch R.J. Tobias P.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 5320-5325Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (237) Google Scholar). Thus while LBP plays a catalytic role in the formation of LPS·sCD14 complexes for binding to non-mCD14 bearing cells, LBP does not have a strictly catalytic role in the presentation of LPS to mCD14 bearing cells. Hailman et al.(7Hailman E. Lichenstein H.S. Wurfel M.M. Miller D.S. Johnson D.A. Kelley M. Busse L.A. Zukowski M.M. Wright S.D. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 269-277Crossref PubMed Scopus (617) Google Scholar) have shown that LPS·sCD14 complexes at 500 ng/ml LPS and 3 μg/ml sCD14 are agonists for neutrophils in the absence of LBP. However, Weingarten et al.(23Weingarten R. Sklar L.A. Mathison J.C. Omidi S. Simon S. Ulevitch R.J. Tobias P.S. J. Leukocyte Biol. 1993; 53: 518-524Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar) have shown that 0.01 ng/ml LPS was a direct agonist for neutrophils in whole blood. Thus the presence of LBP can apparently make 4 orders of magnitude difference in the ability of LPS to activate neutrophils. Similar effects are seen with monocytes (24Mathison J.C. Tobias P.S. Wolfson E. Ulevitch R.J. J. Immunol. 1992; 149: 200-206PubMed Google Scholar) and this may be related to association of LBP with the cells. It is also known that the in vitro activation of peripheral blood monocytes is some 1000-fold more sensitive to LPS than is the activation of endothelial cells and it has been proposed that the LPS-sCD14 pathway for activation of LPS-sCD14-sensitive cells exposed to blood is probably secondary to their activation by LPS elicited monocyte derived cytokines (25Pugin J. Ulevitch R.J. Tobias P.S. J. Exp. Med. 1993; 178: 2193-2200Crossref PubMed Scopus (136) Google Scholar). This hypothesis is supported by the measurements of KDfor FITC-LPS complexes of sCD14 and LBP; sCD14 binds FITC-LPS some 10-fold less tightly than LBP. The fact that FITC-LPS is actually transferred to sCD14 in our experiments despite the fact that sCD14 binds FITC-LPS some 10-fold less tightly than LBP is a result of the fact that sCD14 was present at much higher concentration than LBP. However, in serum (or plasma), LBP and sCD14 are normally present at roughly equal concentrations. One would thus predict that in serum, LPS would predominantly associate with LBP. During an acute-phase response, LBP concentrations are considerably elevated, more so than sCD14. Thus after an acute-phase response, the balance of LPS bound to LBP and sCD14 would shift further to LBP, further diminishing the ability of LPS to stimulate cells via the LPS-sCD14 pathway. Thus although an important role for LBP catalysis of LPS binding to sCD14 is readily demonstrable in vitro, the role of this reaction in vivo remains to be defined. Perhaps it will be found at extravascular sites of sCD14 synthesis where the ratio of sCD14:LBP could be quite different from plasma (26Fearns C. Loskutof D. J. Exp. Med. 1995; 181: 857-866Crossref PubMed Scopus (142) Google Scholar).

L-selectin, the leukocyte selectin, mediates the carbohydrate-dependent attachment of circulating leukocytes to endothelium, preceding emigration into tissues. It functions in inflammatory leukocyte trafficking and in lymphocyte homing to lymph nodes. From previous work, the binding of L-selectin to endothelial-associated glycoprotein ligands, GlyCAM-1 and CD34, requires oligosaccharide sialylation, sulfation, and probably fucosylation. We have recently identified a major capping group in GlyCAM-1 as 6′ sulfated sialyl Lewis x, a novel structure which potentially satisfies all of these requirements. In the present study, we define the complete structure of β-eliminated chains of GlyCAM-1 using metabolic radiolabeling, plant lectin binding, and glycosidase digestions in conjunction with high pH anion-exchange chromatography. The majority of the O-glycans in GlyCAM-1 contain the T-antigen, i.e. Galβ1→3GalNAc, which is incorporated into the core-2 structure, i.e. Galβ1→3[GlcNAcβ1→6]GalNAc or larger core structures with additional GlcNAc residues. The structures of two O-glycans, based on core-2, were determined to be: The implications of these structures and more complex O-glycans for binding by L-selectin are discussed. In the present study, we have undertaken a complete analysis of GlyCAM-1 to define the nature of the oligosaccharide core structures beneath the capping group. We establish that the O-glycans contain core-2 (i.e. GlcNAcβ1→6[Galβ1→3]-GalNAc) as a main core structure. We present complete structures for the simplest of the major O-linked chains and provide information about the more complex glycans. This new information raises a number of considerations for how recognition by L-selectin is achieved. Digestions with jack bean β-galactosidase were carried out at 0.25 units/ml in 100 µl of 20 mM NaH2PO4 (buffered to pH 3.5 with acetic acid) for 12 h at 37 °C. Digests and parallel controls were then subjected to gel filtration through Bio-Gel P4 as described above. Parallel samples of Galβ1→4(SO4-6)GlcNAc (1 mM) were incubated either with D. pneumoniae β(1→4)galactosidase (0.1 unit/ml) in buffer A or jack bean β-galactosidase (0.25 unit/ml) in 20 mм NaH2PO4, pH 3.5, for 12 h at 37 °C. Digests and parallel controls were then subjected to HPAEC. Samples were lyophilized, each redissolved in 1 ml of 50 mм HC1 in anhydrous methanol, and incubated 24 h at 37 °C. The solvent was evaporated under an argon stream, residues were dried overnight in vacuo, and redissolved in 200 µl of water. These were passed over parallel DEAE anion exchange columns (HCOO– form, 80 mm × 5 mm), equilibrated in 2 mM pyridine-formate, pH 3. Each column was washed with 5 ml of H2O. Flow-through and wash were pooled, lyophilized, and redissolved in 25 µl of water for HPAEC. O-Linked chains obtained by β-elimination (with concomitant reduction) were fractionated by HPAEC using a Carbopac Alditol Prototype column (250 mm × 4 mm) from Dionex (Sunnyvale, CA), which was kindly provided by Dr. R. Townsend (University of California, San Francisco). Each sample was injected in 25 µl of water. The column was eluted (flow rate 0.4 ml/min) isocratically for 5 min with 100 mM NaOH, then from 5 to 35 min with a linear gradient of 100–700 mM NaOH, and finally for 15 min isocratically with 700 mM NaOH. Standards were used at 0.25 mM and analyzed by pulsed amperometric detection. Radiolabeled products were detected by collecting 0.5 min (0.2 ml) fractions followed by liquid scintillation analysis as described above. β-Galactosidase digests of Galβ1→4(SO4-6)GlcNAc (1 mM substrate, see above) were injected (25 µl) into a Carbopac PA1 column (Dionex, 250 mm × 4 mm) and eluted (1 ml/min) for 5 min isocratically with 50 mM sodium acetate, 150 mM NaOH, and then from 5 to 35 min with a linear gradient of 50–850 mM sodium acetate in 150 mM NaOH. Eluting carbohydrates were detected by pulsed amperometric detection. Galactose and N-acetylglucosamine-6-sulfate (V-labs, Covington, LA) were used as standards at 0.4 mM. The goal of this study was to define the structures of the simplest O-linked glycans in GlyCAM-1. To obtain radiolabeled chains for this analysis, mouse lymph nodes were metabolically labeled in organ culture with [3H]Gal, [3H]GlcN, or [3H]Man, and GlyCAM-1 was immunoprecipitated from conditioned medium with a peptide-directed antibody as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The label from the [6-3H]galactose precursor is known to be incorporated into galactose units, and the [6-3H]glucosamine precursor is converted into GalNAc, GlcNAc, and sialic acid (28Varki A. FASEB J. 1991; 5: 226-235Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). Reflecting the absence of N-linked chains within GlyCAM-1, the label from the [2-3H]mannose precursor is incorporated exclusively into fucosyl residues (24Hemmerich S. Bertozzi C.R. Leffler H. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4820-4829Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). Undersulfated GlyCAM-1 was obtained by immunoprecipitating lymph nodes that were cultured in the presence of chlorate, a highly selective metabolic inhibitor of sulfation (29Rapraeger A.C. Krufka A. Olwin B.B. Science. 1991; 252: 1705-1708Crossref PubMed Scopus (1292) Google Scholar). After metabolic labeling, the O-linked chains of GlyCAM-1 were obtained by standard β-elimination conditions (26Imai Y. Rosen S.D. Glycoconj. J. 1993; 10: 34-39Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Chain analysis was performed by digestion with glycosidases followed by analysis of the fragments by gel filtration and HPAEC. PNA, a lectin which preferentially recognizes the T-antigen, i.e. Galβ1→3GalNAc (30Lotan R. Skutelsky E. Danon D. Sharon N. J. Biol. Chem. 1975; 250: 8518-8523Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was used to probe for the presence of this structure within GlyCAM-1. Both normal and undersulfated GlyCAM-1, labeled in [3H]Gal, were examined for their binding to PNA-agarose before and after desialylation. It is known that binding of PNA to the T-antigen is not impaired by sialylation at the 6-position of GalNAc but is blocked by α(2→3) sialylation of Gal (31Boland C.R. Chen Y.-F. Rinderle S.J. Resau J.H. Luk G.D. Lynch H.T. Goldstein I.J. Cancer Res. 1991; 51: 657-665PubMed Google Scholar). Fully sialylated GlyCAM-1 did not bind to PNA, whereas desialylated GlyCAM-1 was recognized (Table I). This result suggested the possibility that GlyCAM-1 contains sialylated Galβ1→3GalNAc. We have previously shown that treatment of GlyCAM-1 with Newcastle disease virus sialidase, an enzyme with specificity for the α(2→3) linkage of sialic acid, almost completely abrogates binding of GlyCAM-1 to the Sia-specific lectin, Limax flavus agglutinin (25Hemmerich S. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4830-4835Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Taken together, these results suggest that Siaα2→3Galβ1→3GalNAc is present within GlyCAM-1.Table IBinding of GlyCAM-1 to peanut agglutinin is sialidase-dependent Sulfation of monosaccharides in glycans is known to interfere with the ability of exoglycosidases to hydrolyze these units from oligosaccharide chains (25Hemmerich S. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4830-4835Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar, 32Green E.D. Baenziger J.U. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 25-35Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 33Spiro R.G. Bhoyroo V.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 14351-14358Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, we employed undersulfated GlyCAM-1 for our initial studies. Previously, we (24Hemmerich S. Bertozzi C.R. Leffler H. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4820-4829Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar) showed that chlorate reduces sulfate incorporation into GlyCAM-1 by 90%, while [3H]Gal and [3H]glucosamine incorporation are changed only slightly (see “Experimental Procedures”). Moreover, the overall sialylation and fucosylation of the molecule, as measured by specific lectin affinity chromatography, are not significantly altered (18Hemmerich S. Butcher E.C. Rosen S.D. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 180: 2219-2226Crossref PubMed Scopus (247) Google Scholar, 19Imai Y. Lasky L.A. Rosen S.D. Nature. 1993; 361: 555-557Crossref PubMed Scopus (332) Google Scholar, 25Hemmerich S. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4830-4835Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Our previous work also demonstrated that both enzymatic degalactosylation and defucosylation of GlyCAM-1 are strictly dependent on concomitant desialylation, and that release of galactose by β(1→4)galactosidase is greatly enhanced by defucosylation (25Hemmerich S. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4830-4835Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar). Guided by these results, we isolated O-linked chains from undersulfated GlyCAM-1 ([3H]Gal-labeled) and subjected these glycans to the combined action of D. pneumoniae (Dp) exo-β(l→4)galactosidase, Dp exo-β-N-acetylglu-cosaminidase, Streptomyces α(1→3/4)fucosidase plus or minus A. ureafaciens (Au) sialidase. Without sialidase, only trace levels of free Gal were released (Fig. 1). However, with sialidase present, all of the [3H]Gal label was found shifted into smaller fragments and free galactose (Fig. 1). We conclude from these experiments that virtually all of the Galβ1→4 residues of GlyCAM-1 must be capped by sialic acid. From previous results (25Hemmerich S. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4830-4835Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar) obtained with the Newcastle disease virus sialidase and the Sia linkage-specific lectin, Maackia amurensis agglutinin, the linkage of sialic acid to Galβ1→4 is inferred to be α2→3. As shown in Fig. 1, the combined action of sialidase, β(1→4)galactosidase, β-N-acetylglucosaminidase, and α(1→3/4)fucosidase converted the O-glycans from [3H]Gal-GlyCAM-1 into three species: 1) free Gal (55%), 2) a peak that coeluted with Galβ1→3GalNAc-ol (20%, designated #), and 3) larger fragments (25%). These latter species may represent incompletely digested oligosaccharides (see below). O-Glycans were also isolated from GlyCAM-1 that was metabolically labeled with [3H]GlcN. Since this precursor labels sialic acid residues, the glycoprotein was desialylated, and free sialic acid was removed by gel filtration prior to β-elimination. Sialic acid accounted for 34% of the total [3H]GlcN-derived label. The saccharide chains released from the desialylated [3H]GlcN-GlyCAM-1 were digested with a mixture of β(1→4)galactosidase, β-N-acetylglucosaminidase, and α(1→3/4)fucosidase as above. This treatment produced two main peaks, one that coeluted on the P4 column with free GlcNAc and the other with Galβ1→3GalNAc-ol (not shown). If β(1→4)galactosidase was omitted from the digestion mixture, no free GlcNAc was released, indicating that all GlcNAc was subterminal with respect to Galβ1→4. The next step was to identify the structure of the apparent disaccharide coeluting with Galβ1→3GalNAc-ol (peak #, Fig. 1). This material was subjected, along with authentic standards, to HPAEC on a column designed for fractionation of alditols. As shown in Fig. 2, the component eluted from the HPAEC column with Galβ1→3GalNAc-ol and was clearly differentiated from Galβ1→3GlcNAc-ol, Galβ1→4GlcNAc-ol, and Galβ1→6Glc-NAc-ol. Based on this finding, the presence of label from both [3H]Gal and [3H]GlcN in this peak, the elution of the peak in gel filtration, and the PNA-binding results, we assign the disaccharide under peak # as the alditol of Galβ1→3GalNAc (T-disaccharide). We have recently shown that chlorate treatment dramatically increases (from 32 to 80%) the fraction of uncharged chains derived from desialylated GlyCAM-1 (24Hemmerich S. Bertozzi C.R. Leffler H. Rosen S.D. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4820-4829Crossref PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar). The residual charge, which is presumably due to incomplete suppression of sulfation, may account for the incomplete glycosidase digestion seen in Fig. 1. To obtain neutral O-glycans, chains were β-eliminated from undersulfated-desialylated GlyCAM-1 (labeled with [3H]Gal, [3H]GlcN or [3H]Man) and passed through DEAE-Sepharose anion-exchange resin. The neutral (desialylated and unsulfated) chains in the flow-through were then subjected to gel filtration on Bio-Gel P4. As shown in Fig. 3, the glycans fractionated into three distinct populations: peak I centered at 55 ml, peak II centered at 47.5 ml, and peak III centered at 43 ml. The widths and asymmetries of the three peaks suggested microheterogeneity within each population. All three populations contained galactose (derived from [3H]Gal), GlcNAc/GalNAc (derived from [3H]GlcN), and fucose (derived from [3H]Man). The oligosaccharides of P4-peak I (Fig. 3), with label derived from either [3H]Gal or [3H]GlcN, were digested with β(1→4)galactosidase and α(1→3/4)fucosidase with or without N-acetylglu-cosaminidase. Each digest plus an undigested control sample were resubjected to gel filtration thro

Antibodies against the four isoforms of the human plasma membrane Ca2+-ATPase (PMCA) were raised using an N-terminal sequence of the pump as epitope. The antibodies against PMCA isoforms 1, 2, and 3 were not species-specific, e.g. they also recognized the corresponding proteins in rat, whereas that against the human PMCA isoform 4 failed to do so.The tissue distribution of the four isoforms was estimated by Western blot analysis. Two, PMCA1 and PMCA4, were expressed in all tissues tested (with the exception of the choroid plexus, where the former was not detected). In most tissues the signal from the PMCA1 protein exceeded that of PMCA4, the exception being the erythrocyte. The PMCA2 and PMCA3 proteins were only found in neuronal tissues; the PMCA2 protein was present in high concentrations in the cerebellum and in the cerebral cortex. At variance with previous results on mRNA (e.g. the kidney) no other tissues contained the PMCA2 protein. PMCA3 was the other tissue-specific isoform; in agreement with results in the rat, the protein was found in human neuronal tissues, particularly in the choroid plexus, but was practically absent in all other tissues tested. Antibodies against the four isoforms of the human plasma membrane Ca2+-ATPase (PMCA) were raised using an N-terminal sequence of the pump as epitope. The antibodies against PMCA isoforms 1, 2, and 3 were not species-specific, e.g. they also recognized the corresponding proteins in rat, whereas that against the human PMCA isoform 4 failed to do so. The tissue distribution of the four isoforms was estimated by Western blot analysis. Two, PMCA1 and PMCA4, were expressed in all tissues tested (with the exception of the choroid plexus, where the former was not detected). In most tissues the signal from the PMCA1 protein exceeded that of PMCA4, the exception being the erythrocyte. The PMCA2 and PMCA3 proteins were only found in neuronal tissues; the PMCA2 protein was present in high concentrations in the cerebellum and in the cerebral cortex. At variance with previous results on mRNA (e.g. the kidney) no other tissues contained the PMCA2 protein. PMCA3 was the other tissue-specific isoform; in agreement with results in the rat, the protein was found in human neuronal tissues, particularly in the choroid plexus, but was practically absent in all other tissues tested.

Syk is a cytoplasmic protein-tyrosine kinase containing two amino-terminal Src homology 2 domains that is activated following ligation of the B cell antigen receptor. Syk activation in B cells correlates with Syk tyrosine phosphorylation as well as with Syk SH2-mediated association with the tyrosine-phosphorylated Igα and Igβ B cell antigen receptor subunits. Tyrosine-phosphorylated peptide 20-mers representing Igα and Igβ immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motifs were synthesized and found to stimulate the specific activity of Syk by as much as 10-fold in vitro. Maximal phosphopeptide-induced Syk activation required both Syk SH2 domains and phosphorylation of both tyrosine residues present in the immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motif. The biochemical mechanism responsible for the phosphopeptide-induced Syk enzyme activation appears to be a function of Syk autophosphorylation. Our observations suggest the association of Syk tandem SH2 domains with the tyrosine-phosphorylated Igα and/or Igβ immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motifs in B cells stimulates Syk autophosphorylation leading to Syk enzyme activation. Syk is a cytoplasmic protein-tyrosine kinase containing two amino-terminal Src homology 2 domains that is activated following ligation of the B cell antigen receptor. Maximal phosphopeptide-induced Syk activation required both Syk SH2 domains and phosphorylation of both tyrosine residues present in the immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motif. The biochemical mechanism responsible for the phosphopeptide-induced Syk enzyme activation appears to be a function of Syk autophosphorylation. Our observations suggest the association of Syk tandem SH2 domains with the tyrosine-phosphorylated Igα and/or Igβ immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motifs in B cells stimulates Syk autophosphorylation leading to Syk enzyme activation. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1993; 9: 377-410Crossref PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). The tyrosine residues important for this process are present within an 18–20-amino acid sequence conserved among the signal coupling subunits of different types of antigen receptors (2Weiss A. Littman D.R. Cell. 1994; 76: 263-274Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1951) Google Scholar, 3Reth M. Nature. 1992; 338: 383-384Crossref Scopus (1162) Google Scholar). These regions are referred to as immunoreceptor tyrosine activation motifs (ITAMs) and have the consensus sequence (D/E)XXYXX(UL)X6_8YXX(I/L), where D = aspartic acid, E = glutamic acid, Y = tyrosine, I = isoleucine, L = leucine, and X = any amino acid (3Reth M. Nature. 1992; 338: 383-384Crossref Scopus (1162) Google Scholar). Temporally, members of the membrane-associated Src family such as Lyn and Blk have been shown to be activated within seconds of BCR ligation followed by the activation of cytoplasmic Btk and later activation of cytoplasmic Syk (8Saouaf S.J. Mahajan S. Rowley R.B. Kut S.A. Fargnoli J. Burkhardt A.L. Tsukada S. Witte O.N. Bolen J.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 9524-9528Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). Genetic evidence derived from targeted gene disruption of Lyn and Syk in B cell lines, as well as the identification of Btk as the defective enzyme in human and mouse × chromosome-linked immunodeficiencies, has established that each of these classes of PTKs are important for optimal BCR function (12Takata M. Sabe H. Hata A. Inazu T. Homma Y. Nukada T. Yamamura H. Kurosaki T. EMBO J. 1994; 13: 1341-1349Crossref PubMed Scopus (586) Google Scholar, 13Tsukada S. Saffran D.C. Rawlings D.J. Parolini O. Cell. 1993; 72: 279-290Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1147) Google Scholar, 14Vetrie D. Vorechovsky I. Sideras P. Holland J. Davies A. Flinter F. Hammarstrom L. Kinnon C. Levinsky R. Bobrow M. Smith C.I.E. Bentley D.R. Nature. 1993; 361: 226-233Crossref PubMed Scopus (1242) Google Scholar, 15Thomas J.D. Sideras P. Smith C.I.E. Vorechovsky L. Chapman V. Paul W.E. Science. 1993; 261: 355-358Crossref PubMed Scopus (572) Google Scholar, 16Rawlings D.J. Saffran D.C. Tsukada S. Largaespada D.A. Grimaldi J.C. Cohen L. Mohr R.N. Bazan J.F. Howard M. Copeland N.G. Jenkins N.A. Witte O.N. Science. 1993; 261: 358-361Crossref PubMed Scopus (776) Google Scholar). Current genetic and biochemical evidence is compatible with the idea that BCR clustering initially stimulates the membrane-associated Src PTKs resulting in their phosphorylation of Igα and Igβ ITAM tyrosines. The Igα and Igβ tyrosine phosphorylations then serve as membrane proximal binding sites for the tandem Src homology 2 (SH2) domains present in the amino-terminal portion of Syk. During this process Syk is enzymatically activated and tyrosine-phosphorylated. However, the mechanism responsible for the enzymatic activation of Syk is not known. Thus, it is unresolved whether Syk association with the tyrosine-phosphorylated ITAMs, Syk tyrosine phosphorylation, or merely Syk approximation to the plasma membrane account for noted changes in Syk enzyme activity that accompany BCR ligation. Here, we provide evidence that the tandemly phosphorylated ITAMs of the BCR signal coupling Igα and Igβ subunits can activate the enzyme activity of Syk as much as 10-fold in vitro. The mechanism underlying phospho-ITAM-induced Syk enzymatic activation appears to be a function of Syk autophosphorylation. These observations imply that it is the association of Syk with the tyrosine-phosphorylated Igα and/or Igβ ITAMs in B cells that results in Syk autophosphorylation leading to the enhanced specific activity of the Syk PTK. BAL17 (mature IgM+ IgD+) murine B cells were grown in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum, 5 × 10∼5 M 2-mercaptoethanol, and 2 mM l-glutamine. For BCR activation studies, 1 × 107 cells were treated with 10 μg of goat anti-mouse IgM (anti-μ) (Sigma) for the indicated times and lysed as previously indicated (8Saouaf S.J. Mahajan S. Rowley R.B. Kut S.A. Fargnoli J. Burkhardt A.L. Tsukada S. Witte O.N. Bolen J.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 9524-9528Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar). COS-7 cells were grown in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum. For Syk production, 2 × 106 COS-7 cells were transfected with 10 μg of pSVHASyk plasmid DNA in 25 μl of Lipofectamine (Life Technologies, Inc.) and the cells harvested 48 h later. Prendergast M. Fargnoli J. Bolen J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 23642-23647Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Immunoprecipitations, immune complex protein kinase assays, and immunobloting were all conducted as described previously (18Burkhardt A.L. Bolen J.B. Coligan J.E. Kruisbeek A.M. Margulies D.H. Shevach E.M. Strober W. Current Protocola in Immunology. Vol. 11.4. John Wiley & Sons, New York1993: 1-18Google Scholar). For production of HA-tagged Syk, the 5′ oligonucleotide used for PCR subcloning included a methionine initiation codon and the codons for the HA sequence YPYDVPDYA. The final construct yielded HA-Syk in which the HA tag was incorporated immediately prior the normal Syk initiation codon. The Syk double point mutant 2R was constructed by making arginine to alanine point mutations in the Syk SH2 domains (R41A in the first SH2 and R194A in the second SH2) using the p-Alter system (Promega). These mutations abolished all detectable binding of Igα or Igβ ITAM phosphopeptides to 2R (data not shown). Phosphopeptides were prepared using Fmoc (N-(9-fluorenyl)methoxycarbonyl) chemistry employing a solid-phase strategy. Crude peptides were obtained by treating peptidyl-resin samples with trifluoroacetic acid containing phenol or thiocresol and were purified by reverse phase high performance liquid chromatography using a C-18 bonded column with trifluoroacetic acid/acetonitrile/water. The peptides and phosphopeptides utilized for these studies were determined to be monomeric by FPLC Superose 12 chromatography. Peptide identity was confirmed by fast atom bombardment mass spectrometry and amino acid analysis. The results presented in Fig. 1 demonstrate following anti-μ-induced BCR cross-linking that the specific activity of Syk was stimulated severalfold (right panels) and correlated with an increase in Syk tyrosine phosphorylation (second panel on left) over that found in untreated cells. The activation of Syk enzyme activity was reflected by both the capacity of Syk to support elevated tyrosine autophosphorylation (4–6-fold activation; Fig. 1, right panels) and to phosphorylate exogenous substrates such as rabbit muscle enolase (4-fold activation; Fig. 1, right side, lower panel). Phosphoamino acid analysis detected only phosphotyrosine as the products of these immune complex protein kinase assays (data not shown). As previously found in WEHI 231 B cells (8Saouaf S.J. Mahajan S. Rowley R.B. Kut S.A. Fargnoli J. Burkhardt A.L. Tsukada S. Witte O.N. Bolen J.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 9524-9528Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar), we did not detect other PTKs co-immunoprecipitating with Syk in these assays. The change in Syk specific activity observed correlated with the association of Syk with tyrosine-phosphorylated BCR subunits (Fig. 1, left two bottom panels). While the association of Syk with the BCR in this case was monitored by immunoprecipitating Iga, similar complexes were found using antibodies directed against Igβ. Since Igα and Igβ exist primarily as disulfide-linked heterodimers (21Hombach J. Tsubata T. Leclercq L. Stappert H. Reth M. Nature. 1990; 343: 760-762Crossref PubMed Scopus (306) Google Scholar, 22Camphell K.S. Cambier J.C. EMBO J. 1990; 9: 441-448Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 23Hombach J. Lottspeich F. Reth M. Eur. J. Immunol. 1990; 20: 2795-2799Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 24Camphell K.S. Hager E.J. Friedrich R.J. Cambier J.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1991; 88: 3982-3986Crossref PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar), we could not distinguish whether Syk preferentially associated with the tyrosine-phosphorylated a or β subunits. In order to evaluate the contributions of tyrosine phosphorylation and phospho-Iga/Igβ binding to Syk kinase activity, a source of Syk was needed that lacked tyrosine phosphorylation and one in which antibody binding was displaced from locations potentially interfering with functional analyses. A solution to these problems was found by transient expression of HA-tagged Syk in COS-7 cells. Expression of HA-Syk in COS-7 cells resulted in the production of enzyme that lacked detectable tyrosine phosphorylation in vivo (Fig. 2A) but was capable of tyrosine autophosphorylation in anti-HA immune complexes (Fig. 2B). In separate experiments, we determined by tryptic peptide analysis that the autophosphorylation products of anti-Syk immunoprecipitates of HA-Syk derived from COS-7 cells and Syk derived from B cells were indistinguishable (data not shown). To determine whether Syk autophosphorylation affected Syk enzymatic activity, HA-Syk was immunoprecipitated from COS-7 cells and incubated with 1 mM ATP and 5 mM MnCl2 from 30 s to 1 h. Representative samples from the control (no preincubation) and HA-Syk incubated for 30 min with ATP/Mn2+ were then used for immune complex protein kinase assays using enolase as an exogenous substrate. The results of these experiments show that tyrosine phosphorylation of HA-Syk increased as a function of reaction time (Fig. 2C, bottom panel) and correlated with diminished electrophoretic mobility of HA-Syk in SDS gels (Fig. 2C, top panel). As shown in Fig. 2D, autophosphorylation of HA-Syk resulted in an approximately 10-fold increase in the specific activity of the enzyme toward the enolase substrate. In other experiments we found that maximal activation of HA-Syk was obtained by 5 min of preincubation with ATP/Mn2+ at a point prior to detectable shifts in HA-Syk gel mobility (data not shown). Phosphorylated Igβ and Igα ITAMs Stimulate Syk Specific Activity—HA-Syk was incubated with 25 μΜ peptide or phosphopeptide (for sequences see Fig. 3) for 15 min. Kinase buffer containing enolase was then added and the reactions allowed to continue for one minute. The results of this experiment (Fig. 4) show that Syk kinase specific activity as measured by autophosphorylation or phosphorylation of enolase was maximally activated (8–10-fold) by the diphosphorylated Igβ or Igα peptides. The results shown in Fig. 5 (panels A, D, and E) demonstrate that Syk activation by βdiP was peptide concentration-dependent (maximum = 20 μM; half-maximal = 5 μΜ) and that addition of βdiP at 25 μΜ significantly stimulated the rate of Syk autophosphorylation (Fig. 5, panels B and F) and phosphorylation of the enolase exogenous substrate (Fig. 5, panels C and G). The non-phosphorylated (a or β) had no detectable effects on Syk kinase activity (FIG. 4, FIG. 5). Monophosphorylated peptides showed differential capacities to modulate Syk kinase activity (Fig. 4). The peptide representing the Igβ ITAM with phosphotyrosine in the first position (peptide β1P) had no detectable Syk stimulating activity, while the same peptide with phosphotyrosine in the second position (peptide β2P) stimulated in some, but not all assays, Syk autophosphorylation and enolase phosphorylation approximately 2-fold. The phosphorylated half-ITAMs β1/2-1P and β1/2–2P alone or in combination were found to stimulate Syk kinase activity by as much as 3-fold. Increasing the β2Ρ, β1/2-IΡ, β1/2–2P, or β1/2-1P + β1/2–2P peptide concentrations did not further stimulate Syk kinase activity (data not shown).FIG. 4Effect of ITAM peptides and phosphopeptides on Syk protein kinase activity. The phosphorylated reaction products were resolved on SDS-polyacrylamide gels and detected by autoradiography. A, kinase reaction products. B, Syk immunoblots. Quantitation of the results showing the time course of Syk autophosphorylation (B) and enolase phosphorylation (Ci with preincubation with peptide (open circles) or phosphopeptide (closed circles).View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) The results shown in Fig. 6 demonstrate that mutation of the Syk SH2 domains results in Syk enzyme that cannot be stimulated by the addition of Igβ diP even though the double Syk SH2 mutant (2R) was found to be fully capable of being activated by autophosphorylation. Moreover, the results show that autoactivated wild-type Syk was incapable of being further activated by addition of Igβ diP. In similar experiments, Igα diP gave the same results (data not shown). In agreement with several previous studies analyzing the involvement of Syk in BCR responses, the results presented in this report demonstrate in B cells that Syk enzyme activity is stimulated following BCR ligation (Fig. 1). The elevation in Syk specific activity correlated with increased tyrosine phosphorylation of Syk as well as the association of Syk with the tyrosine-phosphorylated Igα and Igβ subunits of the BCR (Fig. 1). In the present study we sought to dissect the relative contributions of phospho-ITAM binding and enzyme tyrosine phosphorylation to the regulation of Syk protein kinase activity. In our analysis HA epitope-tagged Syk was expressed in COS-7 cells to produce Syk molecules that, in contrast to Syk obtained from hemopoietic cell sources, lacked detectable tyrosine phosphorylation (Fig. 2). HA-Syk also possessed an antibody binding site in a defined location distinct from the enzyme functional domains. Using this expression system, we found that the specific activity of Syk could be increased either by autophosphorylation (FIG. 2, FIG. 6) or by addition of diphosphorylated peptide representing the Igα or Igβ ITAM (FIG. 4, FIG. 5). Syk autophosphorylation was found to stimulate enzyme specific activity by as much as 10-fold (FIG. 2, FIG. 6). Since the double SH2 mutant 2R was as equally activated as wild-type Syk following autophosphorylation (Fig. 6), it appears that intramolecular phosphotyrosine-SH2 interactions are not involved in the activation process. Two-dimensional tryptic peptide analysis of the autophosphorylation reactions products revealed a pattern consistent with the presence of several distinct phosphorylation sites (data not shown). Site-specific tyrosine to phenylalanine mutation of several individual candidate sites including tyrosines 130, 317, 342, 345, 519, 520, 623, 624, and 625 did not prohibit autophosphorylation-induced Syk activation in vitro (data not shown). These results suggest there may be multiple sites of phosphorylation leading to in vitro Syk activation. In contrast to non-phosphorylated peptides, biphosphoryl-ated peptides (αdiP and βdiP) corresponding to the Igα and Igβ ITAMs were found to be capable of maximally stimulating Syk protein kinase activity by approximately 10-fold (FIG. 4, FIG. 6). These phosphorylated peptides had no detectable effect on the Syk double SH2 mutant, demonstrating the dependence of functional Syk SH2s in this process (Fig. 6). In other experiments mutation of either SH2 domain was found to yield enzymes with the same phenotype as that of the double SH2 mutant (data not shown). These results suggest that both Syk SH2 domains are required for αdiP- and βdiP-dependent Syk activation. Additional support for this idea was provided by experiments showing that monophosphorylated Igβ ITAM peptides were found to have little or no stimulatory capacity. Furthermore, it is clear that for maximum Syk stimulation the two phosphotyrosines need to be present on the same peptide, since addition of phosphopeptides representing the 1/2 ITAMs (β1/2–1Ρ and β1/2–2P) alone or in combination led to maximal Syk activation of only 3-fold (Fig. 4). Our results show that the αdiP and βdiP phosphopeptides were not capable of further stimulating the activity of auto-phosphorylation-activated Syk (Fig. 6). These observations support the concept that the mechanism underlying αdiP and βdiP stimulation of Syk may be linked to the induction of conformational changes leading to enhanced Syk autophosphorylation. This possibility is supported by results demonstrating that βdiP binding to Syk significantly accelerates the rate of Syk autophosphorylation. These observations are consistent with the idea that Syk autophosphorylation is a major factor in regulating Syk protein kinase activity. These in vitro results lead to the proposal that tandem SH2 mediated binding of Syk to tyrosine-phosphorylated ITAMs in cells elevates the rate of Syk autophosphorylation, resulting in an increase in Syk specific activity and promoting the tyrosine phosphorylation of Syk substrates. Clearly, other PTKs capable of phosphorylating Syk autophosphorylation sites could participate in this process (25Kurosaki T. Takata M. Yamanashi Y. Inazu T. Taniguchi T. Yamamoto T. Yamamura H. J. Exp. Med. 1994; 179: 1725-1729Crossref PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar). During preparation of this manuscript, we were made aware of similar results obtained using the tyrosine-phosphorylated ITAMs of the high affinity IgE receptor β and γ subunits (Shiue, L., Zoller, M. J., and Brugge, J. S., (1995) J. Biol. Chem. 270, 10498–10502). We thank Lily Shiue, Mark Zoller and Joan Brugge for the communication of their results.

A 161-base pair fragment (AB1) ~10 kilobase pairs upstream of the transcription start site of the mouse heme oxygenase-1 gene functions as a basal level and inducer-dependent enhancer. AB1/chloramphenicol acetyltransferase fusion genes stably transfected into mouse hepatoma (Hepa) cells or L929 fibroblasts were activated 7-8- or 17-22-fold, respectively, after treatment of the cells with either CdCl2 or heme. The AB1 fragment is composed largely of three tandem repeats containing two conserved core elements, A and B. Part of core element A (TCCGGAGCTGTG) resembles the consensus-binding site for transcription factor AP-4, whereas core element B (GCTGAGTCANGG) includes the consensus-binding site (TGAGTCA) for the AP-1 family of transcription factors. Nuclear proteins from Hepa cells did not bind to any of the core A elements, but bound to all three copies of the core B element. AB1 derivatives with one or two mutant AP-1-binding elements exhibited reduced but measurable inducer-dependent enhancer activity, but mutation of all three AP-1-binding sites abolished activation by CdCl2 and heme and also by mercury chloride, zinc chloride, H2O2, sodium arsenate, and 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate. Pretreatment of stably transfected L929 cells with protein kinase C inhibitors, but not with tyrosine kinase inhibitors or N-acetylcysteine, abrogated 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-dependent activation of the AB1/chloramphenicol acetyltransferase fusion gene. Induction by H2O2 was unaffected by the kinase inhibitors, but completely abolished by N-acetylcysteine. Heme-dependent induction was not significantly affected by any of these chemicals. Part of core element A (TCCGGAGCTGTG) resembles the consensus-binding site for transcription factor AP-4, whereas core element B (GCTGAGTCANGG) includes the consensus-binding site (TGAGTCA) for the AP-1 family of transcription factors. Nuclear proteins from Hepa cells did not bind to any of the core A elements, but bound to all three copies of the core B element. AB1 derivatives with one or two mutant AP-1-binding elements exhibited reduced but measurable inducer-dependent enhancer activity, but mutation of all three AP-1-binding sites abolished activation by CdCl2 and heme and also by mercury chloride, zinc chloride, H2O2, sodium arsenate, and 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate. Pretreatment of stably transfected L929 cells with protein kinase C inhibitors, but not with tyrosine kinase inhibitors or N-acetylcysteine, abrogated 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate-dependent activation of the AB1/chloramphenicol acetyltransferase fusion gene. Induction by H2O2 was unaffected by the kinase inhibitors, but completely abolished by N-acetylcysteine. Heme-dependent induction was not significantly affected by any of these chemicals.

Among water channel proteins (aquaporins), aquaporin-collecting duct (AQP-CD) is the vasopressin-regulated water channel. Vasopressin causes cAMP production in the renal collecting duct cells, and this is believed to lead to exocytic insertion of water channel into the apical membrane (shuttle hypothesis). AQP-CD contains a consensus sequence for cAMP-dependent protein kinase, residues at positions 253-256 (Arg- Arg-Gln- Ser). To determine the role of this site, Ser-256 was substituted for Ala, Leu, Thr, Asp, or Glu by site-directed mutagenesis. In Xenopus oocytes injected with wild-type or mutated AQP-CD cRNAs, osmotic water permeability (Pf) was 4.8-7.7 times higher than Pf of water-injected oocytes. Incubation with cAMP plus forskolin or direct cAMP injection into the oocytes increased Pf of wild-type, but not mutated, AQP-CD-expressing oocytes, whereas the amounts of AQP-CD expression were similar in wild and mutated types as identified by Western blot analysis. In vitro phosphorylation studies of AQP-CD proteins expressed in oocyte showed that cAMP-dependent protein kinase phosphorylated wild-type, but not mutated, AQP-CD proteins. Phosphoamino acid analysis revealed that this phosphorylation occurred at the serine residue. Moreover, phosphorylation of AQP-CD protein in intact rat kidney medulla tissues was stimulated by incubation with cAMP. Our data suggest that cAMP stimulates water permeability of AQP-CD by phosphorylation. This process may contribute to the vasopressin-regulated water permeability of collecting duct in addition to the apical insertion of AQP-CD by exocytosis. Engagement of the high affinity receptor for immunoglobulin E (FcϵRI) on the surface of mast cells induces tyrosine phosphorylation of numerous cellular proteins. Syk, one of several non-receptor protein tyrosine kinases implicated in FcϵRI signaling, is activated following receptor cross-linking and associates with phosphorylated γ subunits of FcϵRI. We previously showed that the Src homology 2 (SH2) domains of Syk bind with high affinity to the conserved tyrosine-based activation motif (TAM) of the γ subunit in vitro. In this report, we show that a tyrosine-phosphorylated γ TAM peptide induced tyrosine phosphorylation of Syk in RBL-2H3 cell lysates and stimulated Syk kinase activity 10-fold in vitro, with half-maximal activation at 1-2 μM. A similar β subunit TAM peptide showed much lower stimulation of Syk tyrosine phosphorylation and kinase activity. Phosphopeptide-induced activation was inhibited by an antiserum to the carboxyl-terminal tail of Syk, suggesting that those amino acids are also involved in Syk activation. These results indicate that the catalytic domain of Syk may be regulated by intramolecular interactions with adjacent domains and suggest that Syk binding to phosphorylated γ subunits following FcϵRI engagement in vivo stimulates Syk kinase activity.

P- and E-selectins belong to a family of Ca2+-depend-ent lectins and function as receptors for myeloid leukocytes. We have described a panel of monoclonal antibodies which recognize a sialoglycoprotein from human neutrophils and HL-60 promyelocytic cells and inhibit adhesion of these cells to P-selectin. In this study, we show that the E-selectin receptor-globulin (E-selectin Rg) affinity chromatography can isolate specifically only one glycoprotein from [3H]glucosamine-labeled HL-60 cells in a Ca2+-dependent manner. This protein has a molecular mass of –120 kDa under reducing conditions, which appears to be identical with the previously characterized glycoprotein ligand for P-selectin. The molecule can be cross-depleted by and cross-bound to the E- and P-selectin columns. The chromatographic profile of desialylated O-linked carbohydrates from molecules purified by P- and E-selectin affinity chromatography are identical. Both have five structures at 12.8, 9.8, 6.3, 3.5, and 2.5 glucose units. PL5 monoclonal antibody to the P-selectin sialoglycoprotein ligand, E-selectin Rg, and antiserum to P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 (PSGL-1) all recognize the purified P-selectin ligand on ligand blots and immunoblots. Furthermore, PL5 monoclonal antibody blocks adhesion of HL-60 cells and human neutrophils to E-selectin Rg. Taken together, our results demonstrate that the P- and E-selectin ligand defined in this study is PSGL-1 and suggest that this molecule is an important leukocyte ligand for both P- and E-selectins. Recently, a mucin-like transmembrane protein, called PSGL-1, 1The abbreviations used here are: PSGL-1, P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1; P/ESGL-1, P- and E-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1; Rg, receptor-globulin; mAb, monoclonal antibody; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline at pH 7.4; PAGE, Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; IgG, immunoglobulin G; BSA, bovine serum albumin; SLe”, Siaa2–3Galβ1-4(Fucal-3)GlcNAc; HBSS, Hank's balanced salt solution with CaCl2 and MgCl2.1The abbreviations used here are: PSGL-1, P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1; P/ESGL-1, P- and E-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1; Rg, receptor-globulin; mAb, monoclonal antibody; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline at pH 7.4; PAGE, Polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis; IgG, immunoglobulin G; BSA, bovine serum albumin; SLe”, Siaa2–3Galβ1-4(Fucal-3)GlcNAc; HBSS, Hank's balanced salt solution with CaCl2 and MgCl2. has been cloned (9Sako D.
